September 13, 2009: Fiction
ALEX CROSS’S TRIAL, by James Patterson and Richard DiLallo. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) The detective Alex Cross writes a novel about his great-uncle, who fought
the Klan.
SOUTH OF BROAD, by Pat Conroy. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $29.95.) An
unlikely group’s friendship from the ’60s to the ’80s, and from South Carolina to
San Francisco; by the author of "The Prince of Tides."
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
206 BONES, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $26.99.) Temperance Brennan is
accused of mishandling an autopsy.
THE WHITE QUEEN, by Philippa Gregory. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster,
$25.99.) Palace intrigue during the War of the Roses, by the author of "The Other
Boleyn Girl."
THE GIRL WHO PLAYED WITH FIRE, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf, $25.95.) A
Swedish hacker becomes a murder suspect.
THAT OLD CAPE MAGIC, by Richard Russo. (Knopf, $25.95.) A long-married
couple wrestle with dissatisfactions during a Cape Cod weekend; by the author of
“Empire Falls.”
THE ELEVENTH VICTIM, by Nancy Grace. (Hyperion, $25.99.) A prosecutor
turned therapist is drawn back to crime-fighting when her clients start getting
murdered one by one.
EVEN MONEY, by Dick Francis and Felix Francis. (Putnam, $26.95.) A
bookmaker learns that his father, whom he had believed was long dead, was the
chief suspect in the murder of his mother.
DEAD AND GONE, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $25.95.) Sookie Stackhouse
searches for the killer of a werepanther.
SMASH CUT, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $26.99.) A publicity-seeking
lawyer tries to get to the bottom of who murdered a wealthy executive.
DREAMFEVER, by Karen Marie Moning. (Delacorte, $26.) MacKlaya finds herself
under the erotic spell of a Fae master.
THE SWORD OF THE LADY, by S. M. Stirling. (Roc, $25.95.) Adventures in a
postapocalypse America.
ABYSS, by Troy Denning. (Del Rey/Ballantine/Lucas, $27.) In a "Star Wars" book,
Luke Skywalker goes to the Mind Walker’s world to try to redeem the Jedi.
September 13, 2009
Non-Fiction
CULTURE OF CORRUPTION, by Michelle Malkin. (Regnery, $27.95.) President
Obama and his team of tax cheats, petty crooks, influence peddlers and Wall
Street cronies.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed — it has to do with luck and opportunity as well as talent — from the
author of “Blink.”
IN THE PRESIDENT’S SECRET SERVICE, by Ronald Kessler. (Crown, $26.)
Agents and the presidents they protect.
BORN TO RUN, by Christopher McDougall. (Knopf, $24.95.) Secrets of distance
running from a Mexican Indian tribe.
A BOLD FRESH PIECE OF HUMANITY, by Bill O’Reilly. (Broadway, $26.) The
Fox News commentator on his upbringing and career.
THE HEALING OF AMERICA, by T. R. Reid. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) How other
industrialized democracies provide health care for all at a reasonable cost.
A BIG LITTLE LIFE, by Dean Koontz. (Hyperion, $24.99.) The novelist adopts a
dog.
CATASTROPHE, by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$26.99.) Stopping President Obama before he transforms America into a socialist
state.
LIBERTY AND TYRANNY, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions, $25.) A
conservative manifesto from a talk-show host and president of Landmark Legal
Foundation.
ZEITOUN, by Dave Eggers. (McSweeney’s, $24.) The travails of a Syrian-
American man and his family after Hurricane Katrina.
THE SECRET LIFE OF MARILYN MONROE, by J. Randy Taraborrelli. (Grand
Central, $26.99.) Details about Monroe’s foster mother, her father and her
mentally ill mother, as well as about her relationship with the Kennedy brothers.
STRENGTH IN WHAT REMAINS, by Tracy Kidder. (Random House,, $26.) A
medical student survives civil war and genocide in Burundi, and flourishes in the
United States.
THE EVOLUTION OF GOD, by Robert Wright. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) How
Western religions have created a worldview that has room for both science and
the divine.
HOMER’S ODYSSEY, by Gwen Cooper. (Delacorte, $20.) A woman adopts a
